top_comment.text:
Chef Gennaro,

is it possible to obtain super light Gnocchi by using yeast in the dough?
I imagine rolling the dough to 6-8 mm diameter thickish "spaghetti" and let 
it raise (like bread dough would) to about 12-14 mm diameter, cutting the 
spaghetti into individual Gnocchi and finger and/or fork shape them ? 

Regards, Sander Tel.﻿
top_comment.author: sandertel

comments.text:
Oh yes, yeast works like a bat out of hell... more then enough moisture 
present...no worries there... the egg used provides it...
comments.author: sandertel

comments.text:
Hi Jager Meister, I tried it and it works like a charm... Gnocchi is 
somewhat difficult in the fact that it has thge tendency to become wet and 
starts sticking to stuf... I use cornmeal to remedy this... Works for 
handling (on cutting boards and such) but also in case you need to freeze a 
batch of dough or ready made gnocchi...
comments.author: sandertel

comments.text:
I'm not a chef, but I don't think there's enough protein or moisture in the 
gnocchi for the yeast to feed off for a good rise :O not sure 
though...there is egg, 00 and rice flour, so that might be good enough. You 
never know unless you try :D

But I reckon for something light, maybe substitute the 00 flour for self 
raising flour? I assume it would lose a bit of its pasta qualities though :L
comments.author: Jager Meister

top_comment.text:
Love Gennaro and the recipe looks good. But could you turn off the 
subtitles. That was so distracting and I giggled all the way through the 
video. I couldn't concentrate on the actual recipe because the subtitles 
were ridiculous. If it's his accent that doesn't work with whatever 
software you are using, you might want to just turn it off of his videos. I 
can understand him a lot better without them.﻿
top_comment.author: oliverworld

comments.text:
Thanks. I'll try that. Most of his videos are better, but if you watch this 
one, you'll see what I mean.
comments.author: oliverworld

comments.text:
You can turn off the captions yourself. Just click on the 4th icon on the 
left. Our earlier videos are not captioned in house, only automatically 
through Youtube.
comments.author: Jamie Oliver

top_comment.text: He didn't mix the eggs well in. ﻿
top_comment.author: Uranija Zeus

comments.text:
Why so serious everyone? Be nice, I thought cooking is for having fun and 
enjoy something together.

I started mixing everything not good very early because as Ur Papa said I 
ended up with chewing gum if I wasn't carefully enough and pressed out  all 
the air while mixing, and it will mix up later good enough. But every time 
we ate Gnocchi on holidays in Italy they are extremely fluffy so you need 
the air more than the egg. The egg is only for the colour and a bit for the 
taste, not for sticking it all together, if it would be, you would use the 
protein of the egg. But the amylum of the potatoes is enough to keep it all 
together, and the flour is there to absorb some moisture. So everything is 
very logical and I think the results will proof him right.
I always did it with a lot more flour, but I think it is better how he did 
it, I really have to try it out for dinner today.

My trust in traditions relating to food is very big, and I think that is 
the reason why grandma cooks best ;)
comments.author: nanaki18

comments.text:
Yes of course comparing your mothers overcooked veggies to Gennaro makes a

Gennaro has been sweating busting his arse on pots/pans most likely when 
you were still floating around in your fathers scrotum, HAS ABSORBED 
EXPERIENCED LEARNED but you don't care how long he's been cooking and you

This is why your generation can't cook and will never learn anything. You 
want to be all technical sound like a expert/S and then most likely can't

comments.text:

which was a silly idea. Bake them in their jackets, preferably in a little 
amount of salt, this will help draw more moisture away before you prep your 
gnocchi.

top_comment.text:
may i offer a humble tip ?
i don't have a "ricer"...so  as the master of improvising :-)
i used my Colander  and the back of my wooden spoon  it works perfect

also as a secondary tip  my pans that i use are not the type with steel 
handles ... so i wrapped allu foil around the handle to protect it and stop 
horrid smells from entering my food ...still use a kitchen glove though 
just in case you burn your hands ...

Genaro and Jamie  pls do a tour  live show all over europe ...
<3 you guys
cheers and salute﻿

comments.text: You have to use a ricer...
comments.author: leilani johnson

top_comment.text:
Gnocchi. 就是義大利人的麵疙瘩。
但被稱為麵疙瘩，完全是因為他看起來的樣子，與他的口感、風味，完全沒有任何的關係。
Gnocchi的做法，基本上就是將馬鈴薯煮熟之後，壓製成馬鈴薯泥，之後將馬鈴薯泥滾成一小團就口的大小，沾上麵粉揉捏成型備用。
在料理之前，以滾水燙熟，由於馬鈴薯本身的風味比較有些澱粉細部味道，調味大多為清爽的方式。
這是一道義大利由南至北有的料理，更是義大利人應著春季豐收時的慶典級料理。
top_comment.author: 杜小羊

comments.author: Justka B

top_comment.text:
Why can't we mash the potato with a fork? What can we do if we don't have a 
ricer?﻿
top_comment.author: Paige Boda

comments.text:
+Paige Boda The ricer makes the mixture lighter and less gluggy. Using a 
fork is OK, but the gnocchi will be more solid from having the air 
compressed out of it.
comments.author: Richard Ward

comments.text: +born2burn1 I think I can grate it, thank you for the response!
comments.author: Paige Boda

comments.text:
You have two choices. Use a box grater and finely grate it (I prefer this 
as it is faster and gets the job done) or using a sieve or a colander push 
the potato through the holes with a wooden spoon. This takes a bit longer 
but you don't have to hold the hot potato in you hand. Good luck!
comments.author: born2burn1
